title: Quadrilateral
text:
In <a href="Euclidean%20geometry">geometry</a> a quadrilateral is a four-sided <a href="polygon">polygon</a>, having four <a href="Edge%20%28geometry%29">edges</a> (sides) and four <a href="Vertex%20%28geometry%29">corners</a> (vertices). The word is derived from the Latin words "quadri", a variant of four, and "latus", meaning "side". Another name for it is tetragon, derived from greek "tetra" meaning "four" and "gon" meaning "corner" or "angle", in analogy to e.g., <a href="pentagon">pentagon</a>. "Gon" beeing "angle" also is at the root of calling it quadrangle, 4-angle, in analogy to triangle. A quadrilateral with vertices formula_1, formula_2, formula_3 and formula_4 is sometimes denoted as formula_5.
Quadrilaterals are either <a href="simple%20polygon">simple</a> (not self-intersecting), or <a href="complex%20polygon">complex</a> (self-intersecting, or crossed). Simple quadrilaterals are either <a href="convex%20polygon">convex</a> or <a href="concave%20polygon">concave</a>.
The <a href="Internal%20and%20external%20angle">interior angles</a> of a simple (and planar) quadrilateral "ABCD" add up to 360 <a href="degrees%20of%20arc">degrees of arc</a>, that is
This is a special case of the "n"-gon interior angle sum formula: ("n" − 2) × 180°.
All non-self-crossing quadrilaterals <a href="tessellation">tile the plane</a>, by repeated rotation around the midpoints of their edges.
Simple quadrilaterals.
Any quadrilateral that is not self-intersecting is a simple quadrilateral.
Convex quadrilaterals.
In a convex quadrilateral all interior angles are less than 180°, and the two diagonals both lie inside the quadrilateral.
Concave quadrilaterals.
In a concave quadrilateral, one interior angle is bigger than 180°, and one of the two diagonals lies outside the quadrilateral.
Complex quadrilaterals.
A <a href="list%20of%20self-intersecting%20polygons">self-intersecting</a> quadrilateral is called variously a cross-quadrilateral, crossed quadrilateral, <a href="butterfly">butterfly</a> quadrilateral or <a href="bow-tie">bow-tie</a> quadrilateral. In a crossed quadrilateral, the four "interior" angles on either side of the crossing (two <a href="acute%20angle">acute</a> and two <a href="reflex%20angle">reflex</a>, all on the left or all on the right as the figure is traced out) add up to 720°.
Special line segments.
The two <a href="diagonal">diagonal</a>s of a convex quadrilateral are the <a href="line%20segment">line segment</a>s that connect opposite vertices.
The two bimedians of a convex quadrilateral are the line segments that connect the midpoints of opposite sides. They intersect at the "vertex centroid" of the quadrilateral (see below).
The four maltitudes of a convex quadrilateral are the perpendiculars to a side—through the midpoint of the opposite side.

Diagonals.
Properties of the diagonals in quadrilaterals.

"Note 1: The most general trapezoids and isosceles trapezoids do not have perpendicular diagonals, but there are infinite numbers of (non-similar) trapezoids and isosceles trapezoids that do have perpendicular diagonals and are not any other named quadrilateral."
"Note 2: In a kite, one diagonal bisects the other. The most general kite has unequal diagonals, but there is an infinite number of (non-similar) kites in which the diagonals are equal in length (and the kites are not any other named quadrilateral)."

Angle bisectors.
The internal <a href="angle%20bisector">angle bisector</a>s of a convex quadrilateral either form a <a href="cyclic%20quadrilateral">cyclic quadrilateral</a> (that is, the four intersection points of adjacent angle bisectors are <a href="concyclic%20points">concyclic</a>) or they are <a href="Concurrent%20lines">concurrent</a>. In the latter case the quadrilateral is a <a href="tangential%20quadrilateral">tangential quadrilateral</a>.
In quadrilateral "ABCD", if the <a href="bisection%23Of%20angles">angle bisectors</a> of "A" and "C" meet on diagonal "BD", then the angle bisectors of "B" and "D" meet on diagonal "AC".
Bimedians.
The <a href="Quadrilateral%23Special%20line%20segments">bimedian</a>s of a quadrilateral are the line segments connecting the <a href="midpoint">midpoint</a>s of the opposite sides. The intersection of the bimedians is the <a href="centroid">centroid</a> of the vertices of the quadrilateral.

Maximum and minimum properties.
Among all quadrilaterals with a given <a href="perimeter">perimeter</a>, the one with the largest area is the <a href="Square%20%28geometry%29">square</a>. This is called the "<a href="isoperimetric%20inequality">isoperimetric theorem</a> for quadrilaterals". It is a direct consequence of the area inequality
where "K" is the area of a convex quadrilateral with perimeter "L". Equality holds <a href="if%20and%20only%20if">if and only if</a> the quadrilateral is a square. The dual theorem states that of all quadrilaterals with a given area, the square has the shortest perimeter.
The quadrilateral with given side lengths that has the <a href="Maxima%20and%20minima">maximum</a> area is the <a href="cyclic%20quadrilateral">cyclic quadrilateral</a>.

Hence that point is the <a href="Fermat%20point">Fermat point</a> of a convex quadrilateral.
Remarkable points and lines in a convex quadrilateral.
The centre of a quadrilateral can be defined in several different ways. The "vertex centroid" comes from considering the quadrilateral as being empty but having equal masses at its vertices. The "side centroid" comes from considering the sides to have constant mass per unit length. The usual centre, called just <a href="centroid">centroid</a> (centre of area) comes from considering the surface of the quadrilateral as having constant density. These three points are in general not all the same point.
The "vertex centroid" is the intersection of the two <a href="Quadrilateral%23Special%20line%20segments">bimedians</a>. As with any polygon, the "x" and "y" coordinates of the vertex centroid are the <a href="arithmetic%20mean">arithmetic mean</a>s of the "x" and "y" coordinates of the vertices.
The "area centroid" of quadrilateral "ABCD" can be constructed in the following way. Let "Ga", "Gb", "Gc", "Gd" be the centroids of triangles "BCD", "ACD", "ABD", "ABC" respectively. Then the "area centroid" is the intersection of the lines "GaGc" and "GbGd".
In a general convex quadrilateral "ABCD", there are no natural analogies to the <a href="circumcenter">circumcenter</a> and <a href="orthocenter">orthocenter</a> of a <a href="triangle">triangle</a>. But two such points can be constructed in the following way. Let "Oa", "Ob", "Oc", "Od" be the circumcenters of triangles "BCD", "ACD", "ABD", "ABC" respectively; and denote by "Ha", "Hb", "Hc", "Hd" the orthocenters in the same triangles. Then the intersection of the lines "OaOc" and "ObOd" is called the <a href="circumcenter%20of%20mass">quasicircumcenter</a>, and the intersection of the lines "HaHc" and "HbHd" is called the "quasiorthocenter" of the convex quadrilateral. These points can be used to define an <a href="Euler%20line">Euler line</a> of a quadrilateral. In a convex quadrilateral, the quasiorthocenter "H", the "area centroid" "G", and the quasicircumcenter "O" are <a href="collinear">collinear</a> in this order, and "HG" = 2"GO".
There can also be defined a "quasinine-point center" "E" as the intersection of the lines "EaEc" and "EbEd", where "Ea", "Eb", "Ec", "Ed" are the <a href="Nine-point%20circle">nine-point centers</a> of triangles "BCD", "ACD", "ABD", "ABC" respectively. Then "E" is the <a href="midpoint">midpoint</a> of "OH".
Another remarkable line in a convex non-parallelogram quadrilateral is the <a href="Newton%20line">Newton line</a>, which connects the midpoints of the diagonals, the segment connecting these points being bisected by the vertex centroid. One more interesting line (in some sense dual to the <a href="Newton%20line">Newton's</a> one) is the line connecting the point of intersection of diagonals with the vertex centroid. The line is remarkable by the fact that it contains the (area) centroid. The vertex centroid divides the segment connecting the intersection of diagonals and the (area) centroid in the ratio 3:1.
For any quadrilateral "ABCD" with points "P" and "Q" the intersections of "AD" and "BC" and "AB" and "CD", respectively, the circles "(PAB), (PCD), (QAD)," and "(QBC)" pass through a common point "M", called a Miquel point.
For a convex quadrilateral "ABCD" in which "E" is the point of intersection of the diagonals and "F" is the point of intersection of the extensions of sides "BC" and "AD", let ω be a circle through "E" and "F" which meets "CB" internally at "M" and "DA" internally at "N". Let "CA" meet ω again at "L" and let "DB" meet ω again at "K". Then there holds: the straight lines "NK" and "ML" intersect at point "P" that is located on the side "AB"; the straight lines "NL" and "KM" intersect at point "Q" that is located on the side "CD". 
Points "P" and "Q" are called ”Pascal points” formed by circle ω on sides "AB" and "CD".
Taxonomy.
A hierarchical <a href="Taxonomy%20%28general%29">taxonomy</a> of quadrilaterals is illustrated by the figure to the right. Lower classes are special cases of higher classes they are connected to. Note that "trapezoid" here is referring to the North American definition (the British equivalent is a trapezium). Inclusive definitions are used throughout.
Skew quadrilaterals.
A non-planar quadrilateral is called a skew quadrilateral. Formulas to compute its dihedral angles from the edge lengths and the angle between two adjacent edges were derived for work on the properties of molecules such as <a href="cyclobutane">cyclobutane</a> that contain a "puckered" ring of four atoms. Historically the term gauche quadrilateral was also used to mean a skew quadrilateral. A skew quadrilateral together with its diagonals form a (possibly non-regular) <a href="tetrahedron">tetrahedron</a>, and conversely every skew quadrilateral comes from a tetrahedron where a pair of opposite <a href="edge%20%28geometry%29">edge</a>s is removed.
